oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Davis Memorial Carillon at Alfred University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting Davis Memorial Carillon at Alfred University. The only world carillon in the western hemisphere, it contains a total of 43 bells. It was purchased in 1938 by friends and alumni to honor former president Boothe Colwell Davis and his wife. Concerts given twice weekly.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Steinheim at Alfred University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The caption of this postcard reads ""The Steinheim, overlooking the campus of Alfred University, was built as a museum by former president Jonathan Allen. He began building the castle-like structure in 1876 and it was operated by the university until 1953."" The building still remains on campus, but is no longer a museum.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ceramics Building, Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting Binns-Merrill Hall at Alfred University, Alfred N.Y. Home of the N.Y. State College of Ceramics, Binns-Merrill Hall houses sophisticated materials laboratories, faculty offices and classrooms, as well as drawing studios for upperclassmen in the School of Art and Design, the Schein-Joseph International Museum of Ceramic Art, and administrative offices for the School of Art and Design and the Inamori School of Engineering.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: C.T. American Art

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New Ceramics Building, Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting Binns-Merrill Hall at Alfred University, Alfred N.Y. Home of the N.Y. State College of Ceramics, Binns-Merrill Hall houses sophisticated materials laboratories, faculty offices and classrooms, as well as drawing studios for upperclassmen in the School of Art and Design, the Schein-Joseph International Museum of Ceramic Art, and administrative offices for the School of Art and Design and the Inamori School of Engineering.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Agricultural Hall and Dairy Building, State School of Agriculture at Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting the Agricultural Hall and Dairy Building of the N.Y. State School of Agriculture at Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Alfred University Observatory, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting the Alfred University Observatory. Also known as Stull Observatory, it includes four domes housing a Fitz refractor and three reflectors, a 14"" Newtonian, a 16"" Ealing ""Educator"", and a 20"" Newtonian. Throughout the years, the observatory has grown to such a size and stature that it is considered one of the finest teaching observatories in the United States.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carnegie Library, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting the Carnegie Library at Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y. Constructed in 1912, it was the first library building of the University. Former Alfred University student Melvil Dewey, originator of the Dewey Decimal System that was used by many libraries to classify their collections, and University President Boothe Colwell Davis persuaded Andrew Carnegie to fund the construction of the building as a library. When the University's collection outgrew the space, Carnegie Hall was converted to administrative offices

Former Alfred University student Melvil Dewey, originator of the Dewey Decimal System that was used by many libraries to classify their collections, and University President Boothe Colwell Davis persuaded Andrew Carnegie to fund the construction of the building as a library. When the University's collection outgrew the space, Carnegie Hall was converted to administrative offices
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Artvue Post Card Co.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Burdick Hall, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting Burdick Hall at Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y. It was used as a men's dormitory as well as classrooms. In 1868 it was moved to present site of Kanakadea Hall and was used for a Grade School. Courses were taught by both university faculty and district school teachers. It was called the Union Free School District. In 1883, disagreement befell this arrangement and the building was purchased by W. C. Burdick and moved down the hill next to Kanakadea Creek and used as an apartment house. In 1896, now known as Burdick Hall, it was loaned to Alfred University for a men's residence hall. In 1903, it became University property and was used as a men's residence hall until 1959 when it was partially destroyed by fire. It was later torn down. The first floor had the campus union (student lounge, snack bar, and dining room). The building contained rooms for 30 men.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: F.H. Ellis

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Burdick Hall, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting Burdick Hall at Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y, along with a poem written by F. A. Hubold in 1912. Burdick was used as a men's dormitory as well as classrooms. In 1868 it was moved to present site of Kanakadea Hall and was used for a Grade School. Courses were taught by both university faculty and district school teachers. It was called the Union Free School District. In 1883, disagreement befell this arrangement and the building was purchased by W. C. Burdick and moved down the hill next to Kanakadea Creek and used as an apartment house. In 1896, now known as Burdick Hall, it was loaned to Alfred University for a men's residence hall. In 1903, it became University property and was used as a men's residence hall until 1959 when it was partially destroyed by fire. It was later torn down. The first floor had the campus union (student lounge, snack bar, and dining room). The building contained rooms for 30 men.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ladies Hall, Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard depicting The Brick at Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y. The Brick was built in 1858 originally to house women. It has been known as Boarding Hall, University Hall and Ladies Hall, but in 1933 the University permanently adopted the students nickname for the building and it has since been known as The Brick.
